task.Question: How many studio albums were published by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009 (included)? You can use the latest 2022 version of english wikipedia.

Annotator Metadata.Steps:
1. I did a search for Mercedes Sosa
2. I went to the Wikipedia page for her
3. I scrolled down to "Studio albums"
4. I counted the ones between 2000 and 2009

steps.content: How many studio albums were published by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009 (included)? You can use the latest 2022 version of english wikipedia.

steps.reasoning:
1. Perform a WebSearch for "Mercedes Sosa discography" to find relevant information about her studio albums.
   
2. If the search results include a link to her Wikipedia page, use the Browser tool to open that page.

3. On the Wikipedia page, locate the section that lists her studio albums and identify the albums released between 2000 and 2009.

4. Count the number of studio albums published in that time frame.

5. If the information is not clear or complete on Wikipedia, perform an additional WebSearch for "Mercedes Sosa albums released 2000 to 2009" to find more detailed sources.

6. Compile the final count of studio albums published by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009.

1. The specific fact given in the request is the time frame: "between 2000 and 2009 (included)."

2. Facts that need to be looked up include the number of studio albums published by Mercedes Sosa during the specified time frame. This information can be found on her discography page on Wikipedia or other authoritative music databases.

3. No facts need to be derived; the task is to count the number of albums.

4. There are no recalled facts or hunches; the information is specific to the query and requires verification through external sources.

      Haydée Mercedes
      "
      La Negra
      "
      Sosa
      (
      Latin American Spanish:
      
      BID:728 link [meɾˈseðes ˈsosa], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish'
      ; 9 July 1935
      superscript
        BID:731 link [1], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-birth-1'
      – 4 October 2009) was an
      BID:734 link Argentine, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentines'
      singer who was popular throughout
      BID:735 link Latin America, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America'
      and many countries outside the region. With her roots in
      BID:736 link Argentine folk music, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folk_music_of_Argentina'
      , Sosa became one of the preeminent exponents of
      El nuevo cancionero
      . She gave voice to songs written by many Latin American songwriters. Her music made people hail her as the "voice of the voiceless ones".
      superscript
        BID:739 link [2], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-tmc-2'
      She was often called "the conscience of Latin America".
      superscript
        BID:743 link [3], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-3'
    
      Sosa performed in venues such as the
      BID:747 link Lincoln Center, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Center'
      in New York City, the
      BID:748 link Théâtre Mogador, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_Mogador'
      in Paris, the
      BID:749 link Sistine Chapel, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sistine_Chapel'
      in Vatican City, as well as sold-out shows in New York's
      BID:750 link Carnegie Hall, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Hall'
      and the Roman
      BID:751 link Colosseum, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colosseum'
      during her final decade of life. Her career spanned four decades and she was the recipient of six
      BID:752 link Latin Grammy, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy'
      awards (2000, 2003, 2004, 2006, 2009, 2011), including a
      BID:753 link Latin Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award'
      in 2004 and two posthumous
      BID:754 link Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Best_Folk_Album'
      in 2009 and 2011. She won the
      BID:755 link Premio Gardel, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premios_Gardel'
      in 2000, the main musical award in Argentina. She served as an ambassador for
      BID:756 link UNICEF, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNICEF'
      .
    heading Life
      Life
    ​
    [
    BID:762 link edit, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mercedes_Sosa&action=edit&section=1'
    ]
    
      Sosa was born on 9 July 1935, in
      BID:766 link San Miguel de Tucumán, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Miguel_de_Tucum%C3%A1n'
      , in the
      BID:767 link northwestern Argentine, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentine_Northwest'
      province of
      BID:768 link Tucumán, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucum%C3%A1n_Province'
      , of
      BID:769 link mestizo, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mestizo'
      ancestry. She was of French, Spanish and
      BID:770 link Diaguita, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diaguita'
      descent.
      superscript
        BID:772 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
      Her nickname "la negra", which is a common nickname in Argentina for people with darker complexion, is a reference to her indigenous heritage.
      superscript
        BID:776 link [5], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5'
      Her parents, a day laborer and a washerwoman,
      superscript
        BID:780 link [6], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-6'
      were
      BID:783 link Peronists, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peronism'
      , although they never registered in the party, and she started her career as a singer for the
      BID:784 link Peronist Party, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peronist_Party'
      in
      BID:785 link Tucuman, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucum%C3%A1n_Province'
      under the name Gladys Osorio.
      superscript
        BID:787 link [7], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-7'
      In 1950, at age fifteen, she won a singing competition organized by a local radio station and was given a contract to perform for two months.
      superscript
        BID:791 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      She recorded her first album,
      BID:795 link La Voz de la Zafra, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_voz_de_la_zafra'
      , in 1959.
      superscript
        BID:797 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      A performance at the 1965
      BID:800 link Cosquín National Folklore Festival, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosqu%C3%ADn_Festival'
      —where she was introduced and brought to the stage while sitting in the audience by fellow folk singer
      BID:801 link Jorge Cafrune, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Cafrune'
      —
      superscript
        BID:803 link [9], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-test-9'
      brought her to the attention of the Argentine public.
      superscript
        BID:807 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      Sosa and her first husband,
      BID:810 link Manuel Oscar Matus, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Manuel_Oscar_Matus&action=edit&redlink=1'
      , with whom she had one son, were key players in the mid-60s
      BID:812 link nueva canción, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nueva_canci%C3%B3n'
      movement (which was called
      nuevo cancionero
      in Argentina).
      superscript
        BID:815 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      Her second record was
      Canciones con Fundamento
      , a collection of Argentine folk songs.
    figure
      BID:820 link, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa,_F%C3%A9lix_Luna_y_Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez.jpg'
      Figcaption
        Sosa with
        BID:823 link Félix Luna, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Luna'
        and
        BID:824 link Ariel Ramírez, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez'
        (at the piano)
    
      Sosa "spent the late 1960s building her audience in Europe and among the cosmopolitan middle class in Buenos Aires, becoming in the process a much bigger star" than her contemporaries.
      superscript
        BID:827 link [11], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-11'
      In 1967, Sosa toured the United States and Europe with great success.
      superscript
        [
        BID:832 link citation needed, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed'
        ]
      In later years, she performed and recorded extensively, broadening her repertoire to include material from throughout Latin America.
    
      In the early 1970s, Sosa released two concept albums in collaboration with composer
      BID:835 link Ariel Ramírez, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez'
      and lyricist
      BID:836 link Félix Luna, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Luna'
      :
      Cantata Sudamericana
      and
      Mujeres Argentinas
      (Argentine Women). She also recorded a tribute to Chilean musician
      BID:839 link Violeta Parra, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Violeta_Parra'
      in 1971, including what was to become one of Sosa's signature songs,
      BID:841 link Gracias a la vida, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gracias_a_la_vida'
      .
      superscript
        BID:843 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
      superscript
        BID:847 link [12], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-ap-12'
      She further popularized of songs written by
      BID:850 link Milton Nascimento, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milton_Nascimento'
      of Brazil and
      BID:851 link Pablo Milanés, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Milan%C3%A9s'
      and
      BID:852 link Silvio Rodríguez, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silvio_Rodr%C3%ADguez'
      both from
      BID:853 link Cuba, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba'
      .
      superscript
        BID:855 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
      Throughout the decade, she released albums such as
      Hasta la Victoria
      in 1972 and
      Traigo un Pueblo
      
      en mi Voz
      in 1973. They featured songs like "Cuando tenga la tierra", written by
      BID:861 link Ariel Petrocelli, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ariel_Petrocelli&action=edit&redlink=1'
      and Daniel Toro, which tackles political and social issues like wealth and land inequality.
      superscript
        BID:863 link [13], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:2-13'
      superscript
        BID:867 link [14], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-14'
      During the 1970s she was a part of two films by the director
      BID:870 link Leopoldo Torre Nilsson, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopoldo_Torre_Nilsson'
      :
      BID:872 link El Santo de la Espada, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Santo_de_la_Espada'
      in 1970 and
      BID:874 link Güemes, la tierra en armas, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%BCemes:_la_tierra_en_armas'
      in 1971, in which she portrayed
      BID:875 link Juana Azurduy de Padilla, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juana_Azurduy_de_Padilla'
      , the guerrilla military leader who fought for Argentine independence.
      superscript
        BID:877 link [13], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:2-13'
      superscript
        BID:881 link [15], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-15'
    figure
      BID:885 link, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa_2.jpg'
      Figcaption
        Sosa in 1972
    
      After the
      BID:889 link military junta, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Reorganization_Process'
      of
      BID:890 link Jorge Videla, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Videla'
      came to power in 1976, the atmosphere in Argentina grew increasingly oppressive. Sosa faced death threats against both her and her family, but refused for many years to leave the country. At a concert in
      BID:891 link La Plata, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Plata'
      in 1979, Sosa was searched and arrested on stage, along with all those attending the concert.
      superscript
        BID:893 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      Their release came about through international intervention.
      superscript
        BID:897 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      Despite attempts to hold more concerts, she was officially barred from performing by the military regime.
      superscript
        BID:901 link [5], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5'
      Banned in her own country, she moved to Paris and then to
      BID:904 link Madrid, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid'
      .
      superscript
        BID:906 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      superscript
        BID:910 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      She has spoken publicly about her artistic and emotional struggles during this period of her life.
      superscript
        BID:914 link [5], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5'
      While in exile, she released the album
      A Quien Doy
      in 1981. The album included a recording of the song "Cuando Me Acuerdo de Mi Pais" which was originally written by the prolific Chilean singer/songwriter,
      BID:918 link Patricio Manns, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patricio_Manns'
      . The song, which he wrote while also in political exile, expresses the sorrow he felt from being separated from his homeland.
      superscript
        BID:920 link [16], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-16'
      She related to this feeling and struggled to continue recording and performing. In an interview with the New York Times, she said, “It was a mental problem, a problem of morale...It wasn’t my throat, or anything physical".
      superscript
        BID:924 link [5], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5'
    
      Sosa returned to Argentina from her exile in Europe in February of 1982,
      superscript
        BID:929 link [17], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:1-17'
      superscript
        BID:933 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      several months before the military regime collapsed as a result of the
      BID:936 link Falklands War, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falklands_War'
      , and gave a series of concerts at the
      BID:938 link Teatro Ópera, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teatro_Opera'
      in Buenos Aires, where she invited many of her younger colleagues to share the stage. A double album of recordings from these performances became an instant best seller. She then traveled to perform in her home province of Tucuman. However, these performances were largely ignored by mainstream media in the country.
      superscript
        BID:940 link [17], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:1-17'
      In subsequent years, Sosa continued to tour both in Argentina and abroad, performing in such venues as the
      BID:943 link Lincoln Center, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Center'
      in New York City and the
      BID:945 link Théâtre Mogador, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_Mogador'
      in Paris. In poor health for much of the 1990s, she performed a comeback show in Argentina in 1998.
      superscript
        BID:947 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      In 1994, she played in the
      BID:950 link Sistine Chapel, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sistine_Chapel'
      in Vatican City.
      superscript
        BID:952 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
      In 2002, she sold out both
      BID:955 link Carnegie Hall, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Hall'
      in New York and the
      BID:956 link Colosseum, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colosseum'
      in Rome in the same year.
      superscript
        BID:958 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
    figure
      BID:962 link, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa.jpg'
      Figcaption
        Sosa in 1973
    
      A supporter of
      BID:966 link Perón, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Per%C3%B3n'
      , she favored leftist causes throughout her life. She supported President
      BID:967 link Raul Alfonsin, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Alfons%C3%ADn'
      in the election of 1983 which marked the return of democracy in Argentina following the dictatorship. She referred to this election as "Argentina's Spring"
      superscript
        BID:969 link [18], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-18'
      She opposed President
      BID:972 link Carlos Menem, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Menem'
      , who was in office from 1989 to 1999, and supported the election of
      BID:973 link Néstor Kirchner, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C3%A9stor_Kirchner'
      , who became president in 2003.
      superscript
        BID:975 link [19], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-19'
      Sosa was a
      BID:978 link UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO_Goodwill_Ambassador'
      for Latin America and the Caribbean.
      superscript
        BID:980 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      superscript
        BID:984 link [20], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-20'
    
      Sosa disliked being identified as a protest singer.
      superscript
        BID:989 link [21], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-21'
      superscript
        BID:993 link [22], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-22'
      While she was outright in her political stances, Sosa said the following on the position of the artist:
    blockquote
      
        “An artist isn’t political in the party political sense – they have a constituency, which is their public – it is the poetry that matters most of all.”
    
      In a career spanning four decades, she worked with performers across several genres and generations, folk, opera, pop, rock, including
      BID:1000 link Martha Argerich, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Argerich'
      ,
      BID:1001 link Andrea Bocelli, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrea_Bocelli'
      ,
      BID:1002 link David Broza, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Broza'
      ,

    heading Awards

    ​
    [
    BID:1065 link edit, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mercedes_Sosa&action=edit&section=2'
    ]
    
      Sosa won the
      BID:1069 link Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Best_Folk_Album'
      in 2000 (
      Misa Criolla
      ),

        BID:1072 link [25], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-25'

      Acústico

      superscript

      2006 (
      Corazón Libre
      ),
      superscript
        BID:1082 link [27], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-27'
      2009 (
      BID:1086 link Cantora 1, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cantora,_un_Viaje_%C3%8Dntimo'
      , which also won
      BID:1087 link Best Recording Package, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Best_Recording_Package'
      and was nominated for
      BID:1088 link Album of the Year, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Album_of_the_Year'
      ),
      superscript
        BID:1090 link [28], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-28'

      Deja La Vida Volar
      ),
      superscript

      BID:1099 link Konex Foundation, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konex_Foundation'

      BID:1100 link Konex Award, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konex_Award'

steps.overview: Identified 3 studio albums released by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009: 'Corazón Libre' (2005), 'Cantora 1' (2009), and 'Cantora 2' (2009).
steps.long_answer: Mercedes Sosa released three studio albums between 2000 and 2009: 'Corazón Libre' in 2005, and two albums titled 'Cantora 1' and 'Cantora 2' in 2009.
